title: Pian Upe Wildlife Reserve
text:
The Pian Upe Wildlife Reserve is a conservation area in the <a href="Karamoja">Karamoja</a> subregion of northeastern <a href="Uganda">Uganda</a>. It is the second largest conservation protected area in Uganda.
History.
The southern part of the reserve was gazetted as the Debasien Animal Sanctuary in 1958. A government-led project to convert land just south of the Greek River for agriculture threatened the viability of wildlife conservation in the whole area. In 1964 the area was expanded northward and renamed Pian-Upe Game Reserve.
A 2003 proposal to degazette the reserve in order to farm fruit on the land was blocked.
Geology.
There is a hot spring potential for Geothermal tapping at Cheposukunya. Further to that, there are Mercury wells at Mt. Kadam.
The reserve features semi arid climate with one rain season annually.
Biology.
Plants.
Most of the reserve is covered by undisturbed grassland and wooded grassland. Small areas of <a href="Riparian%20forest">riverine woodland</a>, <a href="kopjes">kopjes</a> also exist. Some land is cultivated, and especially the area near the Greek River is threatened by conversion.
Dominant tree species are <a href="Acacia%20seyal">red acacia</a> and <a href="Balanites%20aegyptiaca">desert date</a>. Also present are <a href="Combretum">bushwillows</a>, <a href="Harrisonia%20abyssinica">Harrisonia abyssinica</a> and <a href="Gymnosporia%20senegalensis">red spike-thorns</a>. Shrubs include <a href="Clitoria%20ternatea">butterfly pea</a> and <a href="Capparis%20tomentosa">wooly caper bush</a>. Cultivated areas have many live fences of <a href="Cascabela%20thevetia">yellow oleander</a>.
Common grasses in the grassland are <a href="Hyparrhenia">thatching grass</a> and <a href="Setaria">bristle</a> species. Less common are <a href="Andropogon">beard grasses</a> and <a href="Cymbopogon">lemon grasses</a>. Along the rivers <a href="Setaria%20incrassata">Vlei bristle grass</a> and <a href="Cyperus%20rotundus">red nut sedge</a> dominate. The lower vegetation layer burns every year.
Large mammals.
Although the area once supported healthy populations of <a href="Panthera%20leo">lions</a>, <a href="Loxodonta%20africana">elephants</a>, <a href="Diceros%20bicornis">black rhinos</a> and <a href="Giraffa%20camelopardalis">giraffes</a>, these are now locally extinct. The last giraffe was reportedly poached in 1995. In October 2019 15 giraffes from <a href="Murchison%20Falls%20National%20Park">Murchison Falls National Park</a> where reintroduced in the reserve by <a href="Uganda%20Wildlife%20Authority">UWA</a>. Populations of <a href="Equus%20burchelli">plains zebra</a>, <a href="Taurotragus%20oryx">common eland</a>, are also threatened <a href="Gazella%20granti">Grants gazelle</a>.
The most commonly sighted mammal in the reserve is the <a href="oribi">oribi</a>. Others known to inhabit the area (as of 1996) include: 
Reptiles.
Pian Upe is home to enormous <a href="Python%20sebae">rock pythons</a> and smaller but venomous <a href="Bitis%20arietans">puff adders</a>. Harmless <a href="Lycodonomorphus">water snakes</a> are also found there. 
The largest <a href="Squamata">lizards</a> in Pian Upe are the <a href="Savannah%20monitor">Savannah monitor</a>s. Others in the reserve include the <a href="Agama%20agama">common agama</a> as well as skinks, chameleons and geckos.
